Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen 
a couple weeks ago I showed you how to make

homemade chicken stock and then we made chicken 
noodle soup with it today I'm going to share with

you a recipe that you can also use that chicken 
stock for just to show you how versatile that

stock is we are making duck noodle soup or bamee 
bped toon now bamee is egg noodles which

is what we're gonna use bamee is duck and toon
means to braise so it's a very popular street

food in Thailand the duck is braised in lots of 
spices so good and really easy to do let's get

started so I've got a pot of chicken stock here 
unsalted that I made and if you want to see the

video I'll put the link to the video right up here 
how to make your own chicken stock now I'm going

to add some spices to it okay so I've got here 
some cinnamon sticks some star anis some coriander

seeds and also some Sichuan peppercorns we don't 
have the chance of recurrence you can leave it out

now I toasted these in a saute pan just for a few 
minutes to activate all those aromas I toasted all

of them in one pan but if you're feeling hardcore 
you can do them separately if you want and just

drop these into the soup pot here and I'm also 
going to add some goji berries so goji berries

are dry Chinese berry that's a classic ingredient 
in stews and soups and it's believed to be really

good for you with high antioxidants in terms of 
flavor it doesn't add a whole lot of does have

a mild sweetness so if you don't have it don't 
worry about it but if you're going to get it

look for this at a Chinese grocery grocery store 
don't go to Whole Foods or you'll pay like five

times as much for the same thing okay I'm just 
going to drop these in and now I'm going to add

my seasoning I brought here some soy sauce ooh 
some oyster sauce very nice and also for some

color and some rich molasses flavor some black 
soy sauce if you can't find black soy sauce you

can also use dark soy sauce Chinese dark soy sauce 
but you will need to reduce the amount of regular

soy sauce a little bit because it is saltier and 
you can add more or less of the black soy sauces

depending on what the color looks like and then 
some sweetness I'm going to add some palm sugar

this soup is sort of like a a sweet and salty 
combination but you don't want it overly sweet

when it comes to noodle soups you can always 
adjust at the end there are two ingredients

here that I would recommend you add if you have 
it but I don't happen to have it today and one is

galangal I forgot to bring it but if you haven't 
throated and also pandan leaves just a little bit

but it adds a nice floral aroma to the soup okay 
and now the dark I got here some duck legs and

for this I prefer duck legs but if you have duck 
breasts you can use that but the duck leg also has

bones and it'll help flavor the stalk even more 
so this is just drumsticks and thighs connected

together just going to add them right now now 
if you're wondering well if you're making duck

noodle soup why don't you use duck stock and you 
absolutely can but duck bones is very hard to find

like chicken bones I think is widely available 
and a good thing about chicken stock is that

it's got a neutral enough of a flavor that it can 
accommodate other meats like people use chicken

stock as a base for fish soup even so now my duck 
isn't completely covered you got to fix that by

adding some water if you've got more stuff you 
can add more sauce but I don't so I'm just going

to add a little more water to make sure it's 
covered so I'm going to bring this to a gentle

simmer and then let it simmer for one and a half 
to two hours and so the duck is fork-tender but

I'm going to keep it covered just so that I don't 
lose any volume and then halfway through the duck

is all exposed but I also feel like if I close 
it all the aroma and everything stays in the pod

rather than filling the whole room with it oh and 
if you have a slow cooker yes you can absolutely

throw this in a slow cooker all right so for you 
in a little bit check this out it smells so good

in here all those spices now this being duck 
is naturally going to have a lot more fat than

chicken so as you can see it's a lot of fat now if 
you're making this a day before let it cool put it

in the fridge and you can just lift or scrape all 
that fat off really easily but I need to eat this

right now so I'm just going to skin off that 
set look at that look at all that duck set and

of course you can save this for other cooking if 
you want all right that's nice and clean also at

this point if you're able to scoop off some of the 
spices go for it now I'm going to give it a taste

mmm oh that's good but it does need a little 
kick of seasoning so I'm going to actually

add salt because I'm happy with the level of soy 
sauce and oyster sauce so a little salt remember

this is going over a noodle soup so the noodles 
are going to bring its own sort of liquid and

things like that but if you're eating it like a 
super stew which you could people do this will

probably be perfect here are my noodle assembly 
not complicated and not much different from my

other noodle soup I'm using a thin egg noodles 
for this which tends to be the most popular kind

to go with duck noodle soup of course you can 
use any kind of noodles that you want in terms

of condiment I've got of course chili vinegar and 
I actually highly highly recommend it because the

noodles quite rich salty sweet so the acidity is 
really going to help I got some garlic oil which

is what I used to fry these fried garlic and in 
terms of vegetables for this a little different

so I'm using green leaf lettuce believe it or 
not and if you're thinking lettuce its soup yes

and if you haven't tried it you should I find 
the crunch and the flavor goes really well it's

really refreshing so now I've got some boiling 
water going here and I'm going to first cook

my noodles let that chill out there for a minute 
or two and then you often see in Thailand people

will take chopsticks and sort of thur it and 
that sort of helps it cook more evenly and also

these noodles are often coated in flour so by 
doing this you sort of shaking out the flour in

the middle washing it out into the water so you 
don't get flour bit in the middle that's coming

up Shaco as much water as you can and then step 
right there woo now a quick blend with the bean

sprouts and the bean sprouts just take 15 seconds 
or you know just heat it up a little bit you want

it nice and crunchy all right let's bring on 
the duck one whole hindquarter duck which by

the way is probably bigger than individual get 
in Thailand soup on there very nice a little

garlic oil seriously just make the garlic oil 
ones keep it in your fridge and you will be so

glad you did because now it's so easy to just 
add strong garlic flavor to absolutely anything

some chopped cilantro for freshness some people 
do celery leaves as well Chinese celery but you

just do the inner leaf of celery goes really well 
with duck and a little chili vinegar just look at

this house tender this duck is look as that the 
falling apart that's perfect the I know eating

noodle soup a lot of people like to do chopsticks 
but the reason why I like fork and spoon is I get

to compose a perfect bite every time I want this 
bike to have a little bit of everything in it all

that's good all that flavor the flavor of all 
the spices that dr. super tender it's rich and

comforting but really well balanced with a little

pepper I don't like to make this super spicy 
but I do like a little bit of heat and white

pepper just gives that nice warmth awesome enough 
that smells great so go so I hope you give this
